sec.title: Semigroups
sec.p: Throughout this section, we shall use S to denote a semigroup.
We may always adjoin an identity to S by first choosing an element 1\not \in S and then defining a multiplication on S\cup \{1\} to be multiplication on S with the additionalÂ products
In practice, we may indicate this construction by writing â€œS^{1}â€, which means S^{1}=S\cup \{1\} if S has no identity element, and S^{1}=S otherwise.

An element z\in S is called a zero of S if za=az=z for every a \in S. We may also adjoin a zero to S by first choosing an element z\not \in S and then defining a multiplication on S\cup \{z\} to be multiplication on S with the additional products za=az =z for every a\in S \cup \{z\}. In practice, we may indicate this construction by writing â€œS^{z}â€, which means S^{z}= S\cup \{z\} if S has no zero element, and S^{z}=S otherwise. And when we prefer â€œ0â€ instead of z, we use â€œS^{0}â€ instead of S^{z}. But independent of our choice of notation, any semigroup can have at most oneÂ zero.

If S has a zero 0, then it is customary to use S^{\ast } to denote the set S-\{0\} together with a partial multiplication S^{\ast }\times S^{\ast }\rightarrow S^{\ast } defined only for pairs (a,b)\in S^{\ast }\times S^{\ast } where ab\neq 0. Such a structure is an example of a partial groupoid. On the other hand, if S has a zero and all products are equal to zero, then S is a null semigroup.

Suppose \emptyset \neq A\subset S. Then the subsemigroup T of S generated by A is the intersection of all subsemigroups of S that include A. If T=S, then S is said to be generated by A, and A is a set of generators for S. If A=\{a\} is a singleton set, then the semigroup generated by A is the cyclic semigroup \langle a\rangle generated by a. If S is a monoid and \emptyset \neq A\subset S, then A generates S as a monoid if no proper submonoid of S is a superset ofÂ A.

An element e\in S is an idempotent if e^{2}=e. A semigroup is idempotent (or a band) if all its elements are idempotents. For a, b\in S, we say that a and b commute if ab=ba. If all its elements commute, then S is called a commutative semigroup. Since idempotents in an inverse semigroup commute, every inverse semigroup S contains a commutative idempotent semigroup E_{S}, which consists of all idempotents inÂ S.
For any semigroup S, there is a natural partial ordering of the set E_{S} of idempotents in S,Â namely,

It is easy to show that this ordering â€œ\leq â€ on E_{S} is a partial ordering. Moreover, when S is an inverse semigroup, we may view (E_{S}, \leq ) as a special kind of lattice, namely, a lower semilattice, which is a partially ordered set E where every two elements e, f\in E have a greatest lower bound e\wedge f.

statement.label: Proposition 75.1.
statement.p: If E is a commutative idempotent semigroup. Then E is a lower semilattice under the partial ordering
Conversely, if E is a lower semilattice, then E is a commutative idempotent semigroup under the operation ef=e\wedge f.

sec.p: The equivalence given in 75.1 provides just cause for calling commutative idempotent semigroups semilattices.

Turning to transformation semigroups, we let X be a set and say that a function \alpha mapping a subset D of X into X is a partial transformation of X. The set D is the domain of \alpha and is denoted \mathbf{d}\alpha . The set R comprised of those y\in X such that y=x\alpha for some x\in D is the range of \alpha and is denoted \mathbf{r}\alpha . The cardinal number of \mathbf{r}\alpha is the rank of \alpha . The empty transformation is the empty set \emptyset and may be viewed as the partial transformation whose domain \mathbf{d}\emptyset =\emptyset and whose range \mathbf{r}\emptyset =\emptyset . The empty transformation \emptyset is a zero in the semigroup of partial transformations PT_{X} of X, where PT_{X} is the set of all partial transformations of X and multiplication is function composition. In the special case where X is finite and X=\{1,2,\ldots , n\}, we denote PT_{X} asÂ PT_{n}.

One subsemigroup of PT_{n} is the symmetric inverse semigroup C_{n}, which consists of all \alpha \in PT_{n} that are one-one. The members of C_{n} shall be called charts (as in manifold theory) instead of the usual partial one-one transformations used in algebraic semigroup theory. As we did above, we shall write the charts on the right of the argument.

Another subsemigroup of PT_{n} is the full transformation semigroup T_{n} of \{1,\ldots , n\}, which consists of all \alpha \in PT_{n} that have \mathbf{d}\alpha =\{1,\ldots , n\}. A similar definition of the full transformation semigroup T_{X} of (an arbitrary set) X isÂ obvious.

One of the most popular classes of semigroups is the so-called regular semigroups â€” S is a regular semigroup if for every a \in S there is a b\in S such that aba=a. A regular semigroup S whose idempotents commute is called an inverse semigroup.

sec.title: Semigroup Morphisms and Congruences
sec.p: Let S and T be semigroups and suppose \phi : S\rightarrow T is a function that preserves multiplication, i.e.,

Then \phi is called a morphism, a homomorphism, or a representation. An injective morphism S\rightarrow T is a monomorphism, a faithful representation, or an imbedding (of S into T); a surjective morphism is an epimorphism; and a bijective morphism is an isomorphism.
A bijection of a semigroup S onto a semigroup T is an antiisomorphism if \phi reverses the multiplication,Â i.e.,
If S is also equal to T and if \phi ^{2}=1_{S}, where 1_{S} denotes the identity map S\rightarrow S, then \phi is an involution.

An equivalence relation \rho on S is a left (right) congruence on S if for a, b, c\in S, a\,\rho \,b implies ca\,\rho \,cb (respectively, ac\,\rho \,bc). Moreover, \rho is a congruence on S if it is both a left and a right congruence on S. A congruence \rho on S is a proper congruence if it is neither the universal congruence \omega nor the identity congruenceÂ 1_{S}.

statement.label: Proposition 76.1.
statement.p: Let \rho be an equivalence relation on a semigroup S. Then \rho is a congruence on S if and only if for every a, b, c, d\in S, when a\,\rho \,b and c\,\rho \,d, then ac\,\rho \,bd.

sec.p: For each congruence \rho on a semigroup S, the set S/\rho of equivalence classes becomes a semigroup with multiplication
which is well-defined because \rho is a congruence.

One particularly useful kind of congruence is a Rees Congruence: Recall that an ideal I of a semigroup S is a nonempty subset I of S such that, for every a\in S, both aI and Ia are subsets of I. If I is an ideal of S, then \rho _{I} given by (a, b)\in \rho _{I} if and only if either a=b or both a, b\in I is the Rees Congruence on S relative to the ideal I. The quotient semigroup S/\rho _{I} is a Rees quotient semigroup and is denotedÂ S/I.

Ideals play an important role in semigroup theory: A semigroup S is simple if it has no proper ideals. (An ideal I of S is proper if I \neq S.) A semigroup S with zero is 0-simple if S^{2}\neq 0 and S has no proper nonzero ideals. And a 0-simple semigroup is completely 0-simple if it has a primitive idempotent. (A nonzero idempotent e\in S is a primitive idempotent if it is minimal in the partial ordering on E_{S^{\ast }}.) A completely 0-simple inverse semigroup is called a Brandt semigroup.

We also have ideal extensions: If I is an ideal of a semigroup S, then S is an (ideal) extension of I by S/I. For example, to say that S is an extension of one Brandt semigroup by another means that S contains an ideal I that is a Brandt semigroup and that S/I is also a Brandt semigroup.

sec.title: Greenâ€™s Relations
sec.p: For any semigroup S, we have Greenâ€™s relations \mathcal{L}, \mathcal{R}, \mathcal{D}, \mathcal{H}, and \mathcal{J}. These relations were introduced by J. Green [1], and are defined as follows:

disp-formula.tex-math: \begin{align*} a\mathcal{L}b &\enspace \Leftrightarrow \quad \mathrm{there\ exist}\ x, y\in S^{1}\ \mathrm{such\ that}\ xa=b\ \mathrm{and}\ yb=a; \\ a\mathcal{R}b &\enspace \Leftrightarrow \quad \mathrm{there\ exist}\ u, v\in S^{1}\ \mathrm{such\ that}\ au=b\ \mathrm{and}\ bv =a; \\ a\mathcal{D}b &\enspace \Leftrightarrow \quad \mathrm{there\ exists}\ w\in S\ \mathrm{such\ that}\ a\mathcal{L}w\ \mathrm{and}\ w\mathcal{R}b; \\ a\mathcal{H}b&\enspace \Leftrightarrow \quad a\mathcal{R}b\ \mathrm{and}\ a\mathcal{L}b;\quad \mathrm{and} \\ a\mathcal{J}b &\enspace \Leftrightarrow \quad \mathrm{there\ exist}\ x, y, u, v\in S^{1}\ \mathrm{such\ that}\ xay=b\ \mathrm{and}\ ubv=a. \end{align*}

sec.p: These relations allow one to use â€œegg-box picturesâ€ to visualize (in a some-what orderly fashion) an arbitrary semigroup. For instance, in FigureÂ 60.1 we see the egg-box pictures of the full transformation semigroups T_{1}, T_{2}, and T_{3}. Looking at the egg-box picture of T_{3}, in particular, the cell at â€œlocationâ€ 12/3 and {1, 2} is an \mathcal{H} class. In the picture of T_{3}, we see 13 \mathcal{H} classes. On the other hand, we may see the \mathcal{R} classes by erasing all (interior) vertical lines, and the \mathcal{L} classes by erasing all (interior) horizontal lines. There are three \mathcal{D} classes, corresponding to the three egg-boxes, and the \mathcal{J} classes are equal to the \mathcal{D} classes since T_{3} isÂ finite.

sec.title: Greenâ€™s Lemma I.
sec.p: Let a and b be \mathcal{R}-equivalent elements in a semigroup S and suppose s, t\in S^{1} such that

If L_{a} and L_{b} denote, respectively, the \mathcal{L}-classes containing a and b, then multiplication \rho _{s} : L_{a}\rightarrow L_{b} on the right by s and multiplication \rho _{t} : L_{b}\rightarrow L_{a} on the right by t are mutually inverse \mathcal{R}-class preserving bijections.

sec.title: Greenâ€™s Lemma II.
sec.p: Let a and b be \mathcal{L}-equivalent elements in a semigroup S and suppose s, t\in S^{1} such that

If R_{a} and R_{b} denote, respectively, the \mathcal{R}-classes containing a and b, then multiplication \lambda _{s} : R_{a}\rightarrow R_{b} on the left by s and multiplication \lambda _{t} : R_{b}\rightarrow R_{a} on the left by t are mutually inverse \mathcal{L}-class preserving bijections.

sec.title: Free Semigroups, Free Monoids, and Free Groups
sec.p: The concepts of free semigroups, free monoids, and free groups are introduced and discussed in Â§42. In particular, the idea of presentations for semigroups and groups is discussed in the subsection Congruences and Presentations of Â§42.

sec.title: Categories
sec.p: In this section, we adopt the standard of writing operators on the left. A category \mathcal{C} consists of a class \mathcal{O} of objects of \mathcal{C} and a class \mathrm{Hom}\,\mathcal{C} of morphisms of \mathcal{C} that satisfy the following conditions.

def.p: For every ordered pair A, B\in \mathcal{O}, there is a set \mathrm{Hom}(A, B) of morphisms such that each morphism in Hom belongs to exactly one \mathrm{Hom}(A, B). A morphism \alpha \in \mathrm{Hom}(A, B) is denoted \alpha : A\rightarrow B.
For every pair of morphisms \alpha : A\rightarrow B and \beta : B\rightarrow C, there is a unique \gamma : A\rightarrow C, called the composition â€œ\beta \circ \alpha â€ of \alpha and \beta .
If \alpha : A\rightarrow B, \beta : B\rightarrow C, and \gamma : C\rightarrow D, then (\gamma \circ \beta )\circ \alpha =\gamma \circ (\beta \circ \alpha ).

For each object A, there is a morphism 1_{A} : A\rightarrow A, called the identity morphism, such that for any \beta : B\rightarrow A and any \gamma : A\rightarrow C, we have 1_{A}\circ \beta =\beta and \gamma \circ 1_{A}=\gamma .

sec.p: A functor from a category \mathcal{C}_{1} to a category \mathcal{C}_{2} is a pair of mappings, one from \mathcal{O}_{1} to \mathcal{O}_{2}, and the other from \mathrm{Hom}\,\mathcal{C}_{1} to \mathrm{Hom}\,\mathcal{C}_{2}. Both of these mappings are denoted as F, and they satisfy the following conditions.

def.p: F(1_{A})=1_{F(A)} for all A\in \mathcal{O}_{1},
if \alpha : A\rightarrow B, then F(\alpha ) : F(A)\rightarrow F(B), and if in addition \beta : B\rightarrow C, then F(\beta \circ \alpha )=F(\beta )\circ F(\alpha ).

sec.p: We denote the identity functor on a category \mathcal{C} by 1_{\mathcal{C}}, and we say that categories \mathcal{C}_{1} and \mathcal{C}_{2} are isomorphic if there exists functors F_{1} : \mathcal{C}_{1}\rightarrow \mathcal{C}_{2} and F_{2} : \mathcal{C}_{2}\rightarrow \mathcal{C}_{1} such that F_{2}\circ F_{1}=1_{\mathcal{C}_{1}} and F_{1}\circ F_{2}=1_{\mathcal{C}_{2}}.
